page.title: 08Summit Tunnel
page.content: On the morning of 20th December 1984, a train of tanker wagons became derailed in the centre of Summit Tunnel. The petrol caught fire and the flames emerging from the ventilation shafts were shown around the world in spectacular television pictures. The repairs to the tunnel took eight months to complete and the tunnel re-opened on 19th August 1985. The northern end of the tunnel, which was built by John Stephenson, emerges in Walsden. It was started in 1838 and finished in December, 1840. Some 23 million bricks were used and 1000 men employed. When it was opened it was the longest railway tunnel in the world. It is a great credit to the men who built it that, even after such a crash as the one above, the tunnel didn't collapse and can still be used today.
